title: Dietary intake, plasma homocysteine, and repetitive element DNA methylation in the Multi-Ethnic Study of Atherosclerosis (MESA).
abstract: DNA methylation of repetitive elements may explain the relations between dietary intake, hyperhomocysteinemia, and cardiovascular disease risk. We investigated associations of methyl micronutrient intake and plasma total homocysteine with LINE-1 and Alu methylation in a cross-sectional study of 987 adults aged 45-84 y who participated in the Multi-Ethnic Study of Atherosclerosis (MESA) Stress Study.DNA methylation was estimated using pyrosequencing technology. A 120-item food frequency questionnaire was used to ascertain daily intake of folate, vitamin B12, vitamin B6, zinc, and methionine. Plasma total homocysteine was quantified using a fluorescence polarization immunoassay. Associations of micronutrient intake and homocysteine with LINE-1 and Alu methylation were examined using linear regression. Adjusted differences in %5-methylated cytosines (%5 mC) were examined by categories of predictors using multivariable linear regression models. Intake of methyl-donor micronutrients was not associated with DNA methylation. After adjustment for covariates, each 3 ?mol/L increment of homocysteine corresponded with 0.06 (-0.01, 0.13) %5 mC higher LINE-1 methylation. Additionally, BMI was positively associated with LINE-1 methylation (P trend = 0.03). Participants with BMI ? 40 kg/mÂ² had 0.35 (0.03, 0.67) %5 mC higher LINE-1 than those with normal BMI. We also observed a 0.10 (0.02, 0.19) %5 mC difference in Alu methylation per 10 cm of height. These associations did not differ by sex.Dietary intake of methyl-donor micronutrients was not associated with measures of DNA methylation in our sample. However, higher BMI was related to higher LINE-1 methylation, and height was positively associated with Alu methylation.
categories: Congenital Hereditary and Neonatal Diseases and Abnormalities
